title: Browns Design's "87"
content:
Was browsing the wonderful work of Browns Design today and came across what must either be a silly joke or designer masturbation at its finest.

Can someone explain to me how Johnathan Ellery’s book [“87”](http://web.archive.org/web/20071128121318/http:/www.brownsdesign.com/work/?id=23&subcat=&cat=41&i=118) is not simply a gallery of numerals designed by other artists (type designers)? I find the [copyright page](http://web.archive.org/web/20071128121318/http:/www.brownsdesign.com/work/?id=23&subcat=&cat=41&i=110) particularly amusing, given that it seems none of the content is original. Please tell me I’m missing something.

author: Stephen Coles

comments.content:
Must be one of those “artsy” things where Ellery wants us to contemplate the meanings of “87” and perhaps it’s metaphysical ramifications on our lives.

I don’t think your missing anything Stephen...this book appears to be exactly what you said. A gallery of numbers from different typefaces.

Look for the exciting sequel to Johnathan Ellery’s “87” entitled “69” due out this summer.

I haven’t seen the book. I did visit the link.

Perhaps there is some meaning in the choice and sequencing of type? (If the choice of type used for a book communicates something, cannot multiple such choices say something?) Perhaps this ties in with the arrangement and choice of numbers?

In crude terms, there is about 10-20 bits of information content per font choice and a similar amount for the layout and choice of numbers. Not a huge amount of explicit information content for a book, but perhaps it’s simply well-compressed with a wealth of implicit information lying in wait for those who choose to seek it out.
Be that as it may, it still looks great to me ;-)
A nice antidote to over-designed type specimens.
